misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the sample output shows the index prefixed with 'Found at index: ', this text label must be part of the output for any result of the search, including the failure case (-1).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to distinguish between a UI label intended for a successful search result and a literal sentinel value requirement (printing -1) specified for a failure state. In the Java execution model, the output stream is agnostic to context; the programmer must explicitly branch the logic if the failure output format differs from the success format.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that closing the Scanner object is a local cleanup task for that object alone and does not realize it permanently shuts down the underlying input source (System.in).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java Notional Machine, Scanners are 'wrappers' for InputStreams. When a wrapper is closed, it also closes the stream it wraps. Since System.in is a global resource tied to the standard input of the process, closing it prevents any subsequent parts of the program (if they existed) from reading user input ever again.
